text: Wanted to share this here too since this channel has more people in it :)

attachments.fallback:
[December 16th, 2020 1:08 PM] contextadventure: I gave a talk at the CMU HCI institute recently about the politics of programming and programming language design, through the lenses of liberatory design and “conviviality” as defined by Ivan Illich. You can watch it here: <https://scs.hosted.panopto.com/Panopto/Pages/Viewer.aspx?id=763c8876-8a3f-471f-b7a2-ac41013d095f>
I’d be interested to hear any thoughts from this community.

elements.text: Peek #3 is up!

text: We think this one is particularly cool. It’s going back through history to find the transaction that caused dave to cancel, it’s then replaying that transaction to trace what actually happened and then summarizing it. It’s even showing you the actual state of the form that was submitted at the time.

elements.text: We think this one is particularly cool. It’s going back through history to find the transaction that caused dave to cancel, it’s then replaying that transaction to trace what actually happened and then summarizing it. It’s even showing you the actual state of the form that was submitted at the time.

text: The idea here is that you would never again have to guess why something is what it is

elements.text: The idea here is that you would never again have to guess why something is what it is

text: There’s other neat things happening here as well. The system is figuring out interesting things to put on the cards for each customer based on what you asked for. e.g. knowing that contract value is important for customers it includes it

elements.text: There’s other neat things happening here as well. The system is figuring out interesting things to put on the cards for each customer based on what you asked for. e.g. knowing that contract value is important for customers it includes it

text:
This looks wonderful! I have to admit, it is in that realm of magical enough that it is hard to believe/understand.

I know you are doing teasers right now. But seeing the process of building up to this point would super illustrative. Like what went into making that little card view with the list of customers? Is that some builtin way of displaying lists? Or something custom?

You mentioned it knowing that contract value is important. Is there some metadata that tells it that? Is importance builtin?

I will just say that these teasers are definitely doing their job of interesting me :slightly_smiling_face:

Allowing you to build these sorts of nice UIs for questions you want to ask is really wonderful. This looks like an ideal way to build tools for myself that I always want to build, but can never find the time to. I can’t wait to play with this.

text: Looks excellent

elements.text: Looks excellent

text: <@UK3LH8CF5> what you’re seeing here requires no work from the user beyond having written their application that happens to have customers and the notion of cancellation in it. Working in this system is effectively an exercise in defining the nouns and verbs of the world, which we then utilize to automatically provide stuff like this. The card view is one of 3 ways we know to display collections (card stack, table, and grid). You can think of importance as a kind of contextual score that takes into account _everything_ we know. That includes how often things get asked about or are used in the program, statements you may have made about goals, direct statements of importance, its distance from your current context, etc.

text: Wow, that is pretty wonderful. Really seems like a fantastic implementation of Magic Ink.

elements.text: Wow, that is pretty wonderful. Really seems like a fantastic implementation of Magic Ink.

text: It’s really fun to start thinking about how this applies to other situations. E.g. you had a bug in production, with this system you can perfectly replay the bug, but it turns out the root cause actually happened weeks ago when some bad value was introduced into the system. No worries, it can go back and historically replay the exact cause of that errant value two weeks ago and then you just… fix it

text: Hey guys, here is the full process of solving a sorting problem with MockMechanics. I tried to make a video that's more fun to watch, more "show" less "tell". Any feedback on the new format, length, pacing, etc? Do you prefer the legends to the voiceover? Was anything unclear?  <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y2XgcpGitmM&ab_channel=MockMechanics>

elements.text: Hey guys, here is the full process of solving a sorting problem with MockMechanics. I tried to make a video that's more fun to watch, more "show" less "tell". Any feedback on the new format, length, pacing, etc? Do you prefer the legends to the voiceover? Was anything unclear?

text:
I liked it, although it was a little hard to follow. Definitely had a little "aha" moment at 6:20 when the switch finally worked :grinning:

I think the best-in-class for this type of video is Ben Eater. Here's his latest one - <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BUTHtNrpwiI>

I think he edits it so that it seems like it is live but I am sure he actually carefully scripts and narrates over it. He leaves the little mistakes in (as you did) because I think they are important for understanding.

So basically I think it should still have voiceover but you should also edit/condense it. Stuff like changing colours (which still takes quite a long time, but is conceptually boring) can be whisked past.

Other stuff, I think you need to signpost ahead of time what you are intending to do, then do, then show it working. Like: "Ok, now I'm going to try and make this platform move backwards when I flip the button. First, I'm going to need...". This will help follow the design thought process.

(Personal preference but I also found the music kind of annoying, especially when it changed)

All in all, a really great project, will follow closely!

I think he edits it so that it seems like it is live but I am sure he actually carefully scripts and narrates over it. He leaves the little mistakes in (as you did) because I think they are important for understanding.

So basically I think it should still have voiceover but you should also edit/condense it. Stuff like changing colours (which still takes quite a long time, but is conceptually boring) can be whisked past.

Other stuff, I think you need to signpost ahead of time what you are intending to do, then do, then show it working. Like: "Ok, now I'm going to try and make this platform move backwards when I flip the button. First, I'm going to need...". This will help follow the design thought process.

(Personal preference but I also found the music kind of annoying, especially when it changed)

All in all, a really great project, will follow closely!

text: If the parse fails, can you tab down and edit the parsed steps directly, or do you have to re-word it up top?

elements.text: If the parse fails, can you tab down and edit the parsed steps directly, or do you have to re-word it up top?

text: depend on what you mean by fail, if it picked the wrong params, you can click on the blue guys and it will popup all the other things that could’ve gone there given what you typed. If there are alternative interpretation of the steps, you can pop those open and select one. We don’t let you modify the steps directly, but there’s nothing that prevents it. Though those steps need to be completely unambiguous so you have to type what the system actually knows. e.g. you can’t say “burning” you have to say “on fire” because that’s it’s actual name. You could imagine doing that as more of a spectrum, where you _could_ start typing “burning” and autocomplete would insert “on fire”

text: Thanks Chris, great feedback, I especially liked the signpost idea. I didn't like the music much either but I was experimenting to see if people prefer the videos without my voice (I do have an accent and personally I find videos with accents a little annoying) and I had to put something in its place. I thought about speeding up the boring parts but I thought maybe some people would like to follow along and wouldn't like me to skip anything. Maybe I can solve that problem with just the highlights slowed down on youtube and a full normal speed video on patreon, it could even earn me a bit, we'll see. Thanks again, very good points.

elements.text: Thanks Chris, great feedback, I especially liked the signpost idea. I didn't like the music much either but I was experimenting to see if people prefer the videos without my voice (I do have an accent and personally I find videos with accents a little annoying) and I had to put something in its place. I thought about speeding up the boring parts but I thought maybe some people would like to follow along and wouldn't like me to skip anything. Maybe I can solve that problem with just the highlights slowed down on youtube and a full normal speed video on patreon, it could even earn me a bit, we'll see. Thanks again, very good points.

text:
I guess I'm wondering how ambiguity is resolved. Obviously I don't know the system well but take a query like;
>   'friends of new users that have profile pictures'
It could reasonably be parsed as either (in Cypher QL);
>  (n:User)-[:FRIEND_OF]->(m:User) where m.is_new and n.has_pic
or
>  (n:User)-[:FRIEND_OF]->(m:User) where m.is_new and _*m*_.has_pic
i.e. either "friends of (new users with pic)" or "[friends of (new users)] with pic".

Neither is wrong, but I'm wondering how you choose between them.

elements.text: I guess I'm wondering how ambiguity is resolved. Obviously I don't know the system well but take a query like;
'friends of new users that have profile pictures'
It could reasonably be parsed as either (in Cypher QL);
(n:User)-[:FRIEND_OF]->(m:User) where m.is_new and n.has_pic
or
(n:User)-[:FRIEND_OF]->(m:User) where m.is_new and
m
.has_pic

i.e. either "friends of (new users with pic)" or "[friends of (new users)] with pic".

Neither is wrong, but I'm wondering how you choose between them.

text: yeah, that’s a case where the params might be wrong, e.g. which picture am I limiting on, the one attached to friend or the one attached to new user

elements.text: yeah, that’s a case where the params might be wrong, e.g. which picture am I limiting on, the one attached to friend or the one attached to new user

text:
in the case you’d see something like
> get [the friend’s profile picture]

get [the friend’s profile picture]

text:
which you’d click on and get a list that says:
> the friend’s profile picture
> the users’s profile picture

the friend’s profile picture
the users’s profile picture

text: there are other cases where the entire set of steps changes depending on which meaning of a word you go with. In that case, there are multiple options for the entire set of steps (assuming they’re close in score)
